results.title: 49th Parallel
results.creator_credit: General Film Distributions, Ortus and Michael Powell
results.brief_description: After the sinking of Nazi U-boat 37 by the Royal Canadian Air Force during World War II, six Nazi survivors of the attack reach an Eskimo village and commit every sort of crime in their effort to reach the neutral territory of the U.S. This is an important and effective example of propaganda films. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Leslie Howard, Raymond Massey and Glynis Johns.
results.creator_credit_for_label: General Film Distributions, Ortus and Michael Powell

results.title: 48 hrs = 48 hours [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Lawrence Gordon, Joel Silver and Walter Hill
results.brief_description: 48 Hrs set the blueprint for the successful comedy/action/buddy genre film in Hollywood. Jack Cates (Nick Nolte) is a white renegade cop determined to avenge the murder of several colleagues at the hands of criminals. The only way to find the killers is to allow one of their crew, a street-wise hustler out of jail. Reggie Hammond (Eddie Murphy) is given forty-eight hours leave from jail to assist with the investigation. Hammond and Cates hate one another on sight, but have to learn to work together, perhaps even like each other to crack the case. Murphy was still a member of the television show “Saturday Night Live” when he made his debut film, which broke him in the mainstream. His profane shtick became his signature routine, which would see him through many phases of his bountiful career. The film consists of numerous violent set-ups and shoot-outs as well as exciting action sequences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paramount Pictures, Lawrence Gordon, Joel Silver and Walter Hill

results.title: 42nd Street
results.creator_credit: Hal B Wallis, Warner Bros Pictures, Vitaphone and Lloyd Bacon
results.brief_description: Here’s your ticket to “Shuffle off to Buffalo” with Ruby Keeler and Dick Powell in this beguiling Busby Berkeley showcase; a bold, enticing feast of choreography and imagination. Warner Baxter stars as Julian Marsh, a tyrannical director of Broadway musicals. When his show’s leading lady, played by Bebe Daniels, breaks her ankle on the eve of opening night, a wide-eyed chorus girl played by Ruby Keeler is thrust into the role. Also stars George Brent, Una Merkel and Dick Powell.

results.title: 42 Up
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “World in action”.
In 1964 a team from Granada Television set out to test the following theory - are children’s lives already mapped out for them by the age of seven? This was the start of a remarkable series which documents groups of children from childhood through puberty to adulthood. Of the original 14 subjects, 11 remain. Now halfway through their lives, how close are they to realising their dreams and ambitions? This enthralling film also starts asking grander questions common to all humans - what is love, what is character, what is success?

results.title: 4000 frames
results.brief_description: An ‘eye opener’ film experiment, this is a single frame film where every frame is discontinuous with the preceding frame. An attempt was made to avoid any type of relationship between frames whether of images, shapes and forms or association of ideas. The film sets out to investigate the way in which we can ‘read’ the content of single frames, when the frames are presented under varying conditions. Some of the images have been carefully composed, while others filmed simply as found objects.

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: 4.50 from Paddington
results.creator_credit: George Gallaccio, Martyn Friend and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
Elspeth McGillicuddy travels from London to St. Mary Mead to visit her old friend Miss Marple, catching the 4.50 train from Paddington. On the way the train draws to a halt and another train draws alongside. In the carriage opposite the blind suddenly snaps up. Glancing across, Mrs McGillicuddy witnesses a sight she will never forget. Almost immediately the train chugs away, leaving the image printed in Mrs. McGillicuddy’s mind - she has witnessed a murder! Stars Joan Hickson as Miss Marple.

results.title: 4 years-6 years = Four years to six years
results.creator_credit: Robert Humble, Dorothy Courtois, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Child”.
By the age of four the child is curious about the world around him. To find out, he is asking thousands of questions. He is also learning not to be afraid. This film shows children in learning situations: on a nature hike; handling animals and other creatures; dealing with their peers. One particularly interesting example is that of Ingrid and Helen, twins who look alike but act differently.

results.title: 4 Vertigo
results.brief_description:
Les LeVeque is a New York-based artist who has produced a number of videos and video installations exploring the cultural implications of technological change. Recently he has been making video works that use Hollywood classics as their starting point, transforming them into sensuous, hallucinatory works which aim to unveil the repressed representations that loiter inside so many ‘wholesome’ American classics. These include ‘2 Spellbound’ (1999), a reworking of Alfred Hitchcock’s ‘Spellbound’ (1945), and ‘Backwards Birth of a Nation’ (2000), in which D.W. Griffith’s 1915 feature film is reversed and re-edited into a 13-minute phantasm. LeVeque’s works have featured at the New York Video Festival, the Sundance Film Festival, the 2000 Whitney Biennial and the Pompidou Centre in Paris.

In ‘4 Vertigo’, Hitchcock’s 128-minute feature film ‘Vertigo’ has been processed anew by capturing one frame for every two seconds of the original movie. The condensed film was duplicated four times, shifting the horizontal or vertical orientation of the frame with each duplication so that the first image is right side up, the next is sideways, then upside down, then sideways, and finally right side up again. This is only evident when the video is examined frame by frame: played at normal speed the result is a stuttering kaleidoscopic engine that gives the viewer a nauseating yet thrilling sensation of physical and psychic
weightlessness. In LeVeque’s treatment the layered plot line and psychological depths of the Hitchcock original are overtaken by the patterns and rhythms of the new aesthetic centrifuge.

LeVeque states: ‘Building on the notion of obsessive looking, I wanted to transform the original movie into a spinning mandala to generate a sensuous viewing where the dramatic narrative becomes unstable and elusive, a viewing experience where the hypnosis of cinematic spectacle is articulated to such a physical degree that it engenders a consciousness of watching.’

results.title: 4 Shorts by Werner Herzog
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog Filmproduktion, Werner Herzog and Walter Saxer
results.brief_description: A compilation of four short documentary films by Werner Herzog, dubbed one of the most eccentric characters in New German Cinema. “How much would a woodchuck chuck”: An offbeat documentary on the annual World Championship of Livestock Auctioneers in the Amish region of Pennsylvania’s Lancaster County. “Woodchuck” includes a series of hilarious interviews showing the complex tongue-twisters, breathing exercises and secret signals used by the contestants. “La Soufriere”: A record of an ardent and unfulfilled journey to the island of Guadaloupe by the director and two cameramen, to see the eruption of volcano La Soufriere. Once there, they find the population has fled before poisonous gas emissions and tremors, save for three men who have stayed to await their impending deaths. The volcano subsides and Herzog withdraws unrequited. “The Great ecstacy of Woodcarver Steiner”: This film studies Walter Steiner, a woodcarver and one of the leading championship ski jumpers in the world. Herzog follows Steiner’s preparation for the Championships in Yugoslavia, setting up cameras on giant ramps to slow down the action by twenty times. “The Flying doctors of East Africa”: An absorbing documentary on the work of an independent group of physicians in remote areas of East Africa.
